Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Molecular Basis of Visual Mate Choice in Butterflies
Award.AbstractNarration:
IOS-1452648: CAREER: The Molecular Basis of Visual Mate Choice in Butterflies

Years of research focused on the Drosophila eye and vertebrate retina have revealed, in fantastic detail, the molecular and developmental basis of vision. However, the molecular basis of visual attraction, i.e. the genes, molecular pathways, and neural circuits that integrate visual cues and direct a behavioral response towards a stimulus, has not been characterized as fully. Work on Heliconius butterflies has shown them to be primarily visual, with mate selection specifically mediated by simple visual cues. This project will utilize these unique features of Heliconius butterflies to characterize the fundamental biological process of visual mate choice. The research is likely to have a variety of broader impacts on science and society. Because divergence in color pattern and mate choice causes speciation in Heliconius butterflies, this research will provide an integrative analysis of the functional mechanisms responsible for the origin of species. Finally, a major educational outreach component of the project will implement new teaching and learning activities for students at secondary, undergraduate and graduate levels.

The fundamental goal of this research project is to characterize the molecular basis of visual mate choice spanning the continuum from organismal biology and behavior all the way to specific neural circuits and functional mutations. This will be achieved using three complementary research projects that integrate genomics, functional genetics, developmental biology, and comparative neurophysiology. Project 1 will generate a reference genome sequence and use genome resequencing data from preference-tested butterflies to map nucleotide changes responsible for divergent mate preference. Project 2 will characterize the developmental basis of visual preference by comparing patterns of gene expression between butterflies with divergent wing color and mate preference, focusing on wing, eye, and nervous system tissues, using a combination of qRT-PCR, in situ hybridization, and RNA-Seq. Project 3 will examine the anatomical and neurophysiological basis for mate preference, as well as functionally test genes associated with mate preference, using comparative analyses of eye anatomy, electrophysiology, and RNAi. All DNA and RNA sequence data will be deposited on the NCBI SRA database. Other data types will be stored locally and made available upon request.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our major research goal was to characterize the functional basis of divergent mate preference and wing color preference cue in one particularly remarkable mimicry system. Our past research revealed that Heliconius butterflies operate largely by visual cues, with mating decisions specifically mediated by a single wing color stimulus. Furthermore, the genetic basis of mate choice behavior is discrete and tightly linked genetically to the locus that controls the wing color preference cue. These features, combined with our on-going efforts to develop genomic and functional genetic tools in butterflies, make this a particularly powerful system with which to characterize the molecular basis of visual attraction – spanning the continuum from organismal biology and behavior all the way to specific genes. The significance of visual mate preference is further accentuated by the fact that it is a critical feature driving speciation, providing a unique opportunity to link genes, brain, and behavior in the origin of species.

Over the course of the project, we investigated the functional basis of visual mate preference in butterflies using complementary research projects that integrated genomics, functional genetics, developmental biology, and comparative neurophysiology. Specifically, we used genetic mapping and genome-wide association approaches to map the genes responsible for wing color and mating behavior in Heliconius butterflies, we examined temporal and spatial patterns of expression of these genes using a combination of in situ hybridization, immunohistochemistry, and transcriptomics, and we functionally validated candidate genes and explored their functions using CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing. Our research has also characterized and compared the neuroanatomy and physiology of butterflies with different mating behaviors using a combination of eye shine and electrophysiology techniques. This project also implemented a number of educational and outreach activities. These included academic activities with students from local elementary and middle schools as well as development of new courses for graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Chicago. Furthermore, PI Kronforst hosted a PBS web-series entitled Urban Nature.
